Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Understanding Ice Adhesion and Nucleation on Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The objective of this GOALI project is to develop a fundamental understanding of ice adhesion and ice nucleation on a variety of surfaces, including hydrophobic, hydrophilic, charged, textured and mixed patterned surfaces. Despite considerable studies and development of easy-ice-release coatings, the fundamental and molecular understanding of ice-coating interfaces and the kinetics of ice nucleation on these surfaces are lacking. In addition, in-situ characterization of ice nucleation and adhesion of these coatings at the molecular level and under-simulated atmospheric ice conditions (for example: high velocity super-cooled water droplet impact) pose a formidable challenge. This proposal will study the influence of coating chemistry, morphology and topography on ice nucleation and adhesion using both experiments and molecular dynamic simulations. Surface sensitive infrared visible sum frequency generation spectroscopy (SFG) will be used to study the buried interface between water (and ice) and model surface coatings. Surface spectroscopy results will be correlated with adhesion of ice using extensive ice tunnel and fan test capabilities available at GE Global Research. A series of hydrophilic, hydrophobic and charged surfaces will be fabricated from short and long chain silane-based functional groups. Also, multiple patterning and advanced nanolithography techniques developed at GE Global Research will be used to create textured substrates. Thereafter, the experimental results will be compared to the molecular dynamics simulation results.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The objective of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding of ice nucleation, which is important in many applications such as wind turbines, aircraft engines and electrical wires. The knowledge gained from this work will aid in developing or enhancing next generation anti-icing coatings that may either significantly delay or prevent ice formation on these surfaces. Realization of such anti-icing coatings can dramatically improve the efficiency and safety of large numbers of operations. This project will support two graduate students who will spend one year at GE Global Research Center in Niskayuna, in addition to their studies at The University of Akron (UA). The experience of working with a group of scientists at GE and the use of their advanced fabrication and measurement facilities will provide important training and education to these students. Several outreach activities that involve co-PI from an industry team teaching the Technology I class at UA and involvement of high school students in research at GE and UA will be undertaken.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF-GOALI: Understanding Ice Adhesion and Nucleation on Surfaces

PI: Ali Dhinojwala (Department of Polymer Science, The University of Akron)

Co-PI: Azar Alizadeh (GE Global Research, Niskayuna, New York)

Scientific Impact: The objective of the NSF-GOALI proposal was to develop a fundamental understanding of ice adhesion and ice nucleation on hydrophobic, hydrophilic, charged, textured and mixed patterned surfaces. The knowledge of ice formation on these surfaces is important in applications such as wind turbines, aircraft engines, power lines, and transport. Designing a coating that can delay ice formation or reduce ice adhesion can have an important economic and societal impact. The scientific challenge is to understand the role of surface chemistry and surface roughness on ice formation. This knowledge will help companies to develop new coatings for ice mitigation. The ice nucleation is also important in understanding ice nucleation and cloud formation, preservation of life at low temperatures, and movement of glaciers.

There were two main directions in this GOALI project. The first direction was to develop an experimental approach to monitor freezing of water next to solid surfaces. We designed a new cooling stage that allowed us to use surface sensitive spectroscopy (SFG) to study the buried interface between water (and ice) and model surface coatings. We also discovered that when salt solution is cooled, the concentrated brine solution segregates next to the sapphire surface and eventually freezes to form salt hydrates. Even though we did not intend to study salt hydrates, these set of results opened up the possibility of understanding how salt could influence the friction in aqueous environments. Three papers were published in JACS on the use of this new instrument to study water and salt solutions.

Extensive experiments on droplet freezing were conducted at GE lab to understand the role of surface topography and modulus of the substrate on ice nucleation. The group at GE designed a chamber that recorded the temperature of the droplet as a function of time using fast infrared and optical cameras. We were able to measure the spreading and freezing kinetics as a function of surface roughness and modulus. The simulation work was conducted at GE and at the University of Akron. Observing freezing of water using conventional molecular dynamics (MD) is very challenging due a limited time window available for simulation. The MD simulation work at GE, with the help of the fastest supercomputers, has captured the freezing of water droplet. The work at GE has resulted in three papers and one review paper published in MRS Bulletin.

Broader Impact: Four graduate students and two undergraduate students were involved in experimental (spectroscopy) and theoretical (MD) work. Dr. Dhinojwala is involved in organizing the District Science Day that is co-sponsored by the University of Akron and the Junior Ohio Academy of Sciences. Around 300-400 science judges are involved in this event every year. The District Fair has grown very rapidly in the last two years with increase in number of students and participation of schools at this event for the first time. Dr. Dhinojwala is co-PI of the NSF-REU program at Akron and over the last four years he has supervised nearly ten undergraduate students and six high school students in his laboratory. Graduate students also were involved in outreach activities such as laboratory instructor in Upward Bound Math and Science program, volunteered to perform science demonstrations at National Inventors Hall of Fame High School, and volunteered as a Super Judge at the Science Fair.
